quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: one blustery evening of the April following their fourth anniversary Honora returned from New York to find her husband seated under the tall lamp in the room he somewhat facetiously called his “den,” scanning the financial page of his newspaper. He was in his dressing gown, his slippered feet extended towards the hearth, smoking a cigarette. And on the stand beside him was a cocktail glass--empty.
title: A Modern Chronicle — Complete
author: Churchill, Winston, 1871-1947

quoteFirst: At present the company seems to be almost exclusively Swiss and German, but all the appliances for living and carrying on the "cure" are thoroughly generous and agreeable. We rose at five this morning, drank our glasses of warm water, and walked till a
quoteLast: , then breakfasted; and from half-past eight to eleven walked to Bad Pfeffers and back again, along a magnificent ravine where the Tamine boils down beneath a tremendous wall of rock, and where it is interesting to see the electric telegraph leaping from the summit, crossing the gulf, and then quietly running by the roadside till it leaps upward again to the opposite summit.
title: George Eliot's Life, as Related in Her Letters and Journals. Vol. 3 (of 3)

quoteFirst: Arthur, about to issue forth at a
quoteLast: on Monday morning to begin work as a cooper's apprentice, felt as if he would find all Saint X lined up to watch him make the journey in working clothes. He had a bold front as he descended the lawn toward the gates; but at the risk of opening him to those with no sympathy for weaknesses other than their own, and for their own only in themselves, it must be set down that he seemed to himself to be shaking and skulking.
title: The Second Generation
author: Phillips, David Graham, 1867-1911

quoteFirst: the course pursued by an epicotyl under these circumstances is shown in Fig. 175. During the whole day, until
quoteLast: , it plainly bowed itself towards the light; and the tip moved over a considerable space. After 6.45 P.M. it moved backwards, or from the window, till 10.40 P.M., when the last dot was made. Here, then, we have a distinct heliotropic movement, effected by means of six elongated figures (which if dots had been made every few minutes would have been more or less elliptic) directed towards the light, with the apex of each successive ellipse nearer to the window than the previous one.
title: The Power of Movement in Plants
author: Darwin, Charles, 1809-1882; Darwin, Francis, Sir, 1848-1925

quoteFirst: Bessie conjectured that he would be busy for the rest of the afternoon, and she took a walk in the park until dusk, when she returned to the house and retired to her own parlor. The dressing-bell rang at a
quoteLast: , as usual, and Mrs. Betts came to assist at her young lady's toilet. Being dressed, Bessie descended to the octagon room, which she found empty.
title: The Vicissitudes of Bessie Fairfax

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: _Christopher_ began towing _Dunraven_, but this was no easy matter, for there was a nasty sea running, the damaged ship would not steer; her stern went down, the sea broke over it and worked its way forward. In this way the night passed, and at 10.15 the next morning _Christopher_ was able to report that she was now only 60 miles west of Ushant and bringing _Dunraven_ towards Plymouth at 4 knots.
title: Q-Ships and Their Story
author: Chatterton, E. Keble (Edward Keble), 1878-1944
